all_text_timv: Gilbert, Henry, 1868-1937. Henry Gilbert correspondence. 1898-1930. 3 items. text txt rdacontent unmediated n rdamedia sheet nb rdacarrier In Rare Books and Manuscripts, University Libraries, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, Pa. (#RBM 9588/VF Lit) Removed from the Rare Books presentation copy of Ernest Guest's At the end of the world: A vision (London, 1929) [call number PR6013.I3325A8 1929, Utopia collection], formerly owned by British poet Molly Holden (nee Gilbert), the author's granddaughter. Unrestricted access. The collection contains a typescript letter from Henry Gilbert, 30 July 1929, to Professor L.P. Jacks, praising his article in Harmsworth's Universal history, and asks if Jacks will accept a copy of his book, At the end of the world, a fictionalized version of Jacks' topic; a letter from anthropologist Bronislaw Malinowski, 28 December 1930, to Henry Gilbert thanking him for a copy of At the end of the world, and thanking him for "your earnest intention to help me and your active and effective way of showing it which I most appreciate; " and a tear sheet of his publisher's blurbs praising his book, Of necessity [1898]. Acquired 2009 Henry Gilbert (1868-1937) was a popular children's author, and the grandfather of the British poet, Molly Holden. Under his own name he wrote the novels Of necessity (1898) and Hearts in revolt (1901), and as Ernest Guest (the main character in Hearts in revolt), he wrote the dystopian novel, At the end of the world. Gilbert, Henry, 1868-1937 Archives. Gilbert, Henry, 1868-1937. Of necessity. Guest, Ernest, 1868-1937. At the end of the world. Novelists, English 20th century. Dystopias in literature. Correspondence. aat Jacks, L. P. (Lawrence Pearsall), 1860-1955, recipient. Malinowski, Bronislaw, 1884-1942, correspondent.

general_note_ssm: In Rare Books and Manuscripts, University Libraries, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, Pa. (#RBM 9588/VF Lit)

Removed from the Rare Books presentation copy of Ernest Guest's At the end of the world: A vision (London, 1929) [call number PR6013.I3325A8 1929, Utopia collection], formerly owned by British poet Molly Holden (nee Gilbert), the author's granddaughter.
notes_summary_ssim: The collection contains a typescript letter from Henry Gilbert, 30 July 1929, to Professor L.P. Jacks, praising his article in Harmsworth's Universal history, and asks if Jacks will accept a copy of his book, At the end of the world, a fictionalized version of Jacks' topic; a letter from anthropologist Bronislaw Malinowski, 28 December 1930, to Henry Gilbert thanking him for a copy of At the end of the world, and thanking him for "your earnest intention to help me and your active and effective way of showing it which I most appreciate; " and a tear sheet of his publisher's blurbs praising his book, Of necessity [1898].
administrative_history_note_ssm: Henry Gilbert (1868-1937) was a popular children's author, and the grandfather of the British poet, Molly Holden. Under his own name he wrote the novels Of necessity (1898) and Hearts in revolt (1901), and as Ernest Guest (the main character in Hearts in revolt), he wrote the dystopian novel, At the end of the world.
